Kolya - Empires & Puzzles Hero Review & Guide

Kolya brings a unique mix of hygiene and havoc to the battlefield. With his massive Shield Guard Mega Minion and an AoE hit that scrubs enemies clean of their buffs, he is a versatile support tank. But does his 2024 stat line hold up in the 2025 meta? Let's verify if he is still fresh or ready for the hamper.
Kolya Review: It's Laundry Day for Your Enemies
Kolya: The Stolid Sentry Who Scrubs the Competition

Kolya is a 5-star Legendary Nature hero from the Garrison family, originally introduced in late 2024 via the Goblin Summon. He brings a refreshingly domestic theme to the battlefield, proving that even in the heat of war, someone has to do the laundry. As a Paladin, he is built to endure, offering a mix of offensive dispel, solid Area of Effect (AoE) damage, and substantial team protection via his unique Mega Minion. While he lacks a costume at this time, his base kit is designed to be a "Swiss Army Knife" of utility, functioning as a tank, flank, or utility support depending on your needs.

The artwork for Kolya is a delightful departure from the usual "grim warrior" or "ethereal mage" tropes. We see a sturdy dwarf meticulously washing what appears to be polka-dotted undergarments (or perhaps a very festive handkerchief) on a washboard. The juxtaposition of his serious, bearded expression with the mundane act of laundry is genuinely funny. The colors are vibrant, dominated by the lush greens of his attire and the bright whites of his laundry, fitting perfectly with his Nature element. It is hard to be intimidated by a guy doing chores, but that is exactly how he catches you off guard.

When we look at Kolya's stats in the context of late 2025, the power creep is evident. With a base Power of 1118 (approx. 1350 at LB2), he sits roughly 150-200 points behind the bleeding-edge heroes released in December 2025, such as Adelitza or the latest Construct heroes. His stats are heavily skewed towards health (base 2047), which is excellent for a meat shield, but his attack and defense values (around 1120 each un-LB) are now considered average or slightly below average for top-tier competitive play. He is no longer a stat monster, but his massive health pool helps him stay relevant.
"Laundry Day" is a multi-faceted skill that provides immense value in a single cast.
The skill dispels one buff (the latest one) from

enemies before dealing damage. This is a critical mechanic, allowing him to strip defensive buffs like Counterattack or Defense Up before his damage lands, ensuring he doesn't kill himself on a Riposte hero.
He deals 300% damage to all enemies. While 300% is modest by modern standards where 400%+ is becoming common, it is respectable for an Average speed hero who also offers this much utility.
He deals extra damage per removed status effect. This is a nice bonus that punishes buff-heavy teams.
This is the crown jewel of his kit. Summoning a Mega Minion with
inherited from the caster is huge. With modern troops and Limit Breaks, this minion can easily exceed 2000-2500 HP, effectively doubling Kolya's survivability.

The Mega Minion acts as a passive cleanser, removing the latest ailment from all allies at the end of every turn. This "set and forget" cleansing is incredibly powerful against DoT (Damage over Time) heavy teams or periodic debuffers.
Let's break down the mechanics to see what Kolya really brings to the table.
Average. He requires 10 tiles to charge, or 9 with a standard level 23 mana troop (or lower with family/talent bonuses).
With a base Limit Broken attack of around 1216 (LB1), a 300% hit deals significant widespread damage. If he removes buffs from 5 enemies, the multiplier increases to 330%.
If you use a Legendary Troop providing +15% HP, Kolya's HP can push 3000+, making his Minion a ~2000 HP wall.
The minion hits hard. If Kolya has 1400 Attack, the minion inherits effective attack stats that allow its physical hits to feel like weak special skills.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
family and comes with sturdy passives that reinforce his role as a stabilizer.
The Garrison family typically offers bonuses related to defense or health modification resistances, further cementing his tankiness.
This is a top-tier passive. It prevents controllers like the classic Waterpipe or modern mana cutters from shutting him down. It guarantees that once he charges, he is likely to fire.

Wither is a debilitating status that lowers stats permanently for the match. Having a passive that cleanses this specifically from all allies every 4 turns is a niche but potentially game-saving ability in long fights against Wither-heavy meta teams.

is a decent Aether Power for him. While a defensive power might have suited his tank role better, the Attack Up ensures that his 300% AoE and his Mega Minion's hits remain threatening, preventing him from being ignored by the attacker.

Upon release in late 2024, Kolya was seen as a "Swiss Army Knife" of the Nature element—excellent everywhere but not necessarily "broken" in one specific way. He was a staple in many defenses due to the sheer annoyance of his Mega Minion.

In the current meta of late 2025, pure damage dealers have surpassed his 300% output significantly. Heroes now routinely hit for 450%+ to all or have much faster speeds. However, utility ages better than damage. His 65% HP Mega Minion is still one of the beefiest shields in the game.

, particularly in War and Rush formats. He has transitioned from a premier main tank to a top-tier flank or offensive support. The "Safe Cleanse" from his minion is a mechanic that counters many modern ailments without triggering secondary punishment effects. He is solid, reliable, and frustrating to kill.

Kolya is a Paladin, which grants him a chance to boost defense when damaged. Given that his primary value is survival and his Mega Minion's HP scales off his own, a defensive build is generally preferred.
Maximizes the HP of his Mega Minion. A beefier Kolya means a beefier minion, which means more turns of passive cleansing.
Lowers his direct damage output and the slap damage from the minion.
Increases the 300% AoE damage and makes the Mega Minion hit much harder (since it inherits 180% attack).
The minion is slightly easier to destroy.

path is recommended. The utility of the Mega Minion staying alive to cleanse your team turn after turn far outweighs a bit of extra damage. You want that minion to be a second hero in front of your hero.
65% HP inheritance is massive, creating a huge damage sponge.
Automatic cleansing via the minion saves you from wasting turn actions on support skills.
Dispelling before damage prevents suicide against reflectors.
Passive immunity to mana cuts ensures reliability.
In a Very Fast meta, Average speed can sometimes be too slow without high-level mana troops.
Heroes who destroy Mega Minions or prevent minion summoning effectively neuter half his kit.
His defense stat is starting to look average against modern 1300+ Attack snipers.
Excellent tank or flank. His minion forces attackers to bring specific counters.
He becomes an absolute monster. Firing early means the Mega Minion is up almost immediately, protecting the team from the start.
The passive cleanse and durability make him incredibly safe for auto-playing hard map stages.
He dispels the enemy buffs, removing their advantage.
Pair Kolya with other Mega Minion or heavy overheal heroes (like Hathor or a modern Construct). The layers of HP become insurmountable for burst teams.
Use him alongside fast hitters. Kolya stabilizes the board, stripping defenses and cleansing, while snipers pick off the weakened targets.
Heroes specifically designed to one-shot Mega Minions are his worst nightmare.
Heroes like Grimble (classic counter) or modern equivalents that block summoning prevent him from deploying his main asset.
If an enemy steals his Mega Minion (if mechanics allow or via future hero types), it would be disastrous, though rare.

If you pulled Kolya, congratulations. He is a roster anchor. Max him immediately. He will likely be your main tank or flank for a long time. Focus on keeping him alive; do not worry about his damage numbers. His job is to keep

Kolya is still a valuable asset for depth in Wars. He might not make your primary defense team if you have the latest 2025 God-tier heroes, but he is a staple for your 2nd or 3rd War team. He is worthy of Limit Break 1, but think twice about spending Alpha Aethers (LB2) unless you use him in your main defense or really love the character; his stats are decent, but better options for Alpha Aethers exist in the current heavy power-creep era.
The community reaction to Kolya was a mix of amusement and appreciation for his balanced kit.
Players loved the "Laundry Day" concept. One user joked,
"I hope he’s whipping his cloth across the opponent lol."
"One of the most all around heroes in game."
"Perhaps he is so bad at doing laundry that his boxer reek so badly that it damages enemies?"
While some hoped for him to be broken, the consensus settled on him being
which usually means a hero has good longevity without getting nerfed.

Kolya is the hero you didn't know you needed until you realized your team was full of dirty laundry (status ailments). He cleans up messes, sponges up damage, and hits back with a wet towel of justice. While his stats are slowly showing their age as we approach 2026, his mechanical utility remains pristine.
A solid, reliable keeper who will serve you well, provided you don't expect him to be the fastest gun in the west. He is there to win the war of attrition.
